text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.

-- Government to privatise insurer GAN and its banking subsidiary CIC before June 30, 1998. European authorities expected to approve a 23.7 billion francs restructuring plan. Buyer will be expected to sell half of the group's international network within a year after privatisation, GAN's property assets are also to be sold before end 1998.
-- Finance Ministry says purchase by Carrefour of a 41 percent stake in supermarkets group Cora has not had a significant impact on competition.
-- Finance Ministry denies firms with a different financial year would be taxed more heavily.

-- Bill on wealth tax includes an end to additional taxation for 1999, rate of corporate profit tax should be brought down to 40 percent in 1999 from 41.6 percent in 1997 and 1998, and reach 36.6 in the year 2000.
-- Air France chairman Christian Blanc said he presented Prime Minister Lionel Jospin with a preliminary assessment of the company ahead of a possible privatisation.
-- European authorities to look at plans for the privatisation of Credit Lyonnais before the end of the week.
-- Industrialists more optimistic about the overall French economic situation, orders and investment outlook improving.
-- Insurer Axa -UAP chairman Claude Bebear presents Paris area authorities with a project for a private health insurance system to complement social security.
-- Unions criticise a 43-hour working week planned for certain sectors of the hotel industry.
-- Finance Ministry confirms increase in corporate tax will also apply to some 1996 earnings by companies whose financial year does not end on December 31.
